title: Jeremiah Chapter 28 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 28 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 28 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 28.

questions.question: Who was the king of Judah at the beginning of the events in Jeremiah chapter 28?
questions.correctAnswer: Zedekiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:1 mentions the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah king of Judah.

questions.question: Where did Hananiah the prophet speak to Jeremiah?
options: In the house of the LORD
In the palace of the king
questions.correctAnswer: In the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:1 states that Hananiah spoke to Jeremiah in the house of the LORD.

questions.question: What did Hananiah prophesy the LORD had done regarding the yoke of the king of Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Broken the yoke
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:2 says the LORD proclaimed that He had broken the yoke of the king of Babylon.

questions.question: According to Hananiah's prophecy, how soon would the vessels of the LORD's house be brought back?
questions.correctAnswer: Within two full years
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:3 states the vessels would be returned within two full years.

questions.question: Who did the LORD say He would bring back to Judah along with the captives?
questions.correctAnswer: Jeconiah the son of Jehoiakim
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:4 mentions that the LORD would bring back Jeconiah the son of Jehoiakim.

questions.question: How did Jeremiah initially respond to Hananiah's prophecy about the vessels and captives returning?
options: He said Amen and hoped the words would come true
questions.correctAnswer: He said Amen and hoped the words would come true
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:6 records Jeremiah saying 'Amen' and wishing the prophecy would come to pass.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 28:9, how can a prophet who prophesies peace be known as truly sent by the LORD?
options: When the word comes to pass
questions.correctAnswer: When the word comes to pass
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:9 explains that a prophet of peace is known if the prophecy is fulfilled.

questions.question: What symbolic act did Hananiah perform involving the yoke on Jeremiah's neck?
options: He took it off and broke it
He replaced it with a gold yoke
questions.correctAnswer: He took it off and broke it
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:10 states that Hananiah took the yoke off Jeremiah's neck and broke it.

questions.question: What did Hananiah say the LORD would do to the yoke of Nebuchadnezzar within two full years?
options: Break it from all nations' necks
questions.correctAnswer: Break it from all nations' necks
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:11 records Hananiah saying the LORD would break Nebuchadnezzar's yoke in two years.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah agreed with Hananiah's prophecy without any warning or objection.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah initially said Amen but later received a word from the LORD warning Hananiah's prophecy was false (Jeremiah 28:12-15).

questions.question: What did the LORD tell Jeremiah to say to Hananiah about the yokes he had made?
options: Thou hast broken yokes of wood; but shalt make yokes of iron
Thou hast made yokes of gold
Thou hast made yokes of silver
questions.correctAnswer: Thou hast broken yokes of wood; but shalt make yokes of iron
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:13 says the LORD instructed Jeremiah to tell Hananiah he broke wooden yokes but would make iron yokes.

questions.question: What consequence did the LORD declare for Hananiah because he taught rebellion against Him?
questions.correctAnswer: He would die that year
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:16 states the LORD would cast Hananiah from the earth and that he would die that year.

questions.question: True or False: Hananiah died in the same year he made the false prophecy.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:17 records that Hananiah died in the seventh month of that same year.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah told Hananiah, 'The LORD hath not sent thee; but thou makest this people to trust in a ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: lie
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:15 quotes Jeremiah saying Hananiah caused the people to trust in a lie.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD put a yoke of iron on the nations so they would serve Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:14 states that the LORD put a yoke of iron on the nations to serve Nebuchadnezzar.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 28 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 28 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God's promises in difficult times. Based on Jeremiah 28, what biblical truth would you share about discerning true prophecy?
options: A true prophet's prediction of peace will come to pass
All prophets speak only of war and evil
Prophecies must be accepted without question
questions.correctAnswer: A true prophet's prediction of peace will come to pass
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:9 teaches that a prophet who prophesies peace is recognized when their word comes true, indicating trust in God's true message. This aligns with verses 8 and 9 about discerning true prophecy.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 28 teach us about the importance of obedience to God's word when faced with conflicting messages?
options: Obey only the prophecy that brings comfort
Reject all prophecy that challenges personal desires
Test prophecies by their alignment with God's will and outcome
Ignore prophets and rely on human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Test prophecies by their alignment with God's will and outcome
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:12-15 shows God's word to Jeremiah to warn Hananiah about false prophecy, emphasizing obedience to God's true message rather than human declarations. Jeremiah’s response in verses 5-6 supports this discernment.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to spread hopeful but false promises to others. What does Jeremiah 28 illustrate about the consequences of teaching rebellion against the LORD?
options: God will bless those who spread hope regardless of truth
False teachers will face severe judgment, including death
False teachings are ignored by God
False teachers are rewarded with popularity
questions.correctAnswer: False teachers will face severe judgment, including death
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:16-17 records God's judgment on Hananiah for false prophecy, stating he will die that year for teaching rebellion, highlighting the seriousness of integrity in God's word.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach believers about humility when witnessing to others, especially when others oppose God's word?
options: Stand firm in God's word despite opposition
Compromise the truth to avoid conflict
Agree with false prophets to maintain peace
questions.correctAnswer: Stand firm in God's word despite opposition
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:5-7 shows Jeremiah affirming God's message even when Hananiah opposes him, teaching humility and perseverance in obedience rather than yielding to popular opinion.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity in daily life can we draw from Jeremiah's interaction with Hananiah?
options: Integrity requires speaking truth even when inconvenient
Integrity is flexible according to circumstances
Integrity is not important in spiritual matters
questions.correctAnswer: Integrity requires speaking truth even when inconvenient
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:15 demonstrates Jeremiah calling out Hananiah for falsehood, showing the importance of honesty and integrity in spiritual leadership and personal conduct (verses 5-6, 12-15).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by God's discipline. Based on Jeremiah 28, what biblical truth about God's sovereignty and discipline would you share?
options: God uses even harsh circumstances to fulfill His purposes
God abandons His people in hardship
God's discipline is a sign of rejection
questions.correctAnswer: God uses even harsh circumstances to fulfill His purposes
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:14 explains that God has placed a yoke of iron on nations to serve Babylon, showing His control over events to accomplish His will, which includes discipline for correction.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 28 encourage believers to maintain gratitude and contentment in trials?
options: Trust that God's plans will ultimately restore and bless
Focus only on present suffering without hope
Expect immediate relief from all trials
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God's plans will ultimately restore and bless
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:2-4 shows God's promise to break Babylon's yoke and restore captives and temple vessels, teaching believers to remain hopeful and content, trusting God's restoration.

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 28, how should church leaders exhibit spiritual discipline when confronted by false teaching?
options: Confront false teaching with God's word
Ignore false teaching to keep peace
Allow false teaching to spread unchallenged
questions.correctAnswer: Confront false teaching with God's word
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:5-7 and 12-15 show Jeremiah confronting Hananiah publicly with God's word, modeling spiritual discipline by standing firm against error for the good of the people.

questions.question: A believer is unsure about trusting God's promises amid persecution. How does Jeremiah 28 teach perseverance through trials?
options: Hold fast to God's word even if circumstances are difficult
Doubt God's promises when trials occur
questions.correctAnswer: Hold fast to God's word even if circumstances are difficult
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:6-7 shows Jeremiah saying 'Amen' to Hananiah's prophecy but immediately cautioning to watch for truth, demonstrating perseverance through uncertainty by trusting God’s words.

questions.question: What does the breaking and replacing of the yoke symbolize in Jeremiah 28, and how can that apply to Christian humility?
options: God replaces false hope with His true discipline
Yokes represent freedom from all authority
Breaking yokes means ignoring God's word
questions.correctAnswer: God replaces false hope with His true discipline
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:10-14 tells of Hananiah breaking a wooden yoke and God saying He will place an iron yoke instead, symbolizing God’s true authority and discipline, calling for humility to accept His sovereign correction.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah agreed immediately with Hananiah's prophecy without caution.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah said 'Amen' to Hananiah's words (verse 6) but also warned to listen carefully and discern true prophecy (verses 7-9), showing he did not agree without caution.

questions.question: True or False: Hananiah's prophecy came true, and he lived many years after delivering it.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:16-17 states that Hananiah died the same year because he taught rebellion against the LORD, indicating his prophecy did not come true and he faced God's judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 28 teaches that true prophets are recognized when their word of _______ comes to pass.
questions.correctAnswer: peace
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:9 clearly states that a prophet who prophesies peace is known to be truly sent by the LORD when the prophecy is fulfilled.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 28, what is a key biblical principle for witnessing to others with integrity?
options: Speak God's truth even if it leads to personal loss
Tell people what they want to hear
Avoid difficult truths to maintain popularity
questions.correctAnswer: Speak God's truth even if it leads to personal loss
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:15-17 show Jeremiah confronting false prophecy and the consequences faced by Hananiah, emphasizing the call to integrity and truthfulness regardless of personal cost.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 28 illustrate the importance of spiritual discernment in church fellowship?
options: By urging believers to test prophecies against Scripture and outcomes
By accepting all teachings as equally valid
By ignoring differences to preserve unity
By following the most popular prophet
questions.correctAnswer: By urging believers to test prophecies against Scripture and outcomes
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:7-9 instructs to hear carefully and recognize true prophets by the fulfillment of their words, teaching discernment essential for healthy fellowship.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 28 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 28.

questions.question: Who was the prophet that contradicted Jeremiah's message by prophesying peace and breaking Jeremiah's yoke?
questions.correctAnswer: Hananiah
questions.explanation: Hananiah the son of Azur is identified as the prophet opposing Jeremiah by breaking his yoke in Jeremiah 28:10.

questions.question: What action did Hananiah take to symbolize breaking the yoke of Babylon?
options: He broke the yoke from Jeremiah's neck
He wrote a scroll of peace
questions.correctAnswer: He broke the yoke from Jeremiah's neck
questions.explanation: Hananiah took the yoke from Jeremiah's neck and broke it to symbolize breaking Babylon's oppression, as stated in Jeremiah 28:10.

questions.question: According to Hananiah's prophecy, within how many years would the vessels and captives be returned from Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Two years
questions.explanation: Hananiah prophesied that within two full years the yoke of Babylon would be broken and captives returned (Jeremiah 28:3, 28:11).

questions.question: What object did Jeremiah wear to symbolize the yoke of Babylon's oppression?
questions.correctAnswer: Yoke
questions.explanation: Jeremiah wore a yoke to symbolize submission to Babylon, as referenced in Jeremiah 28:10 and 28:13.

questions.question: What was God’s response to Hananiah breaking the wooden yoke from Jeremiah’s neck?
options: He would replace it with a yoke of iron
He would remove the Babylonian king
questions.correctAnswer: He would replace it with a yoke of iron
questions.explanation: God declared that Hananiah had broken wooden yokes but would make yokes of iron, indicating harsher servitude under Babylon (Jeremiah 28:13).

questions.question: What does the iron yoke symbolize in the context of Jeremiah 28?
questions.correctAnswer: Stronger and unbreakable Babylonian oppression
questions.explanation: The iron yoke symbolizes a more severe and unyielding subjugation by Babylon, as God states in Jeremiah 28:14.

questions.question: What was the fate of Hananiah after his false prophecy against Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: He died the same year
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:17 says Hananiah died in the seventh month of the same year because he taught rebellion against the LORD.

questions.question: Which king of Judah was reigning during the events described in Jeremiah 28?
questions.correctAnswer: Zedekiah
questions.explanation: The chapter opens noting it is the beginning of King Zedekiah's reign in Jeremiah 28:1.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 28, what is the significance of the vessels of the LORD's house mentioned?
options: They represent the temple treasures taken to Babylon
They are symbols of peace offerings
They refer to the Ark of the Covenant
They are idols of foreign gods
questions.correctAnswer: They represent the temple treasures taken to Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:3 refers to vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar from the temple, symbolizing lost sacred items during exile.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah say about prophets who prophesy peace in Jeremiah 28:9?
options: Their prophecy is validated when it comes to pass
They only speak from their own heart
questions.correctAnswer: Their prophecy is validated when it comes to pass
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:9 states that a prophet of peace is recognized as truly sent by the LORD if their prophecy is fulfilled.

questions.question: Which historical context best explains the tension between Jeremiah and Hananiah in this chapter?
options: The Babylonian exile and Judah's submission to Babylonian rule
questions.correctAnswer: The Babylonian exile and Judah's submission to Babylonian rule
questions.explanation: The chapter deals with the Babylonian yoke and captivity, reflecting Judah's historical subjugation (Jeremiah 28:2-4).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah respond initially to Hananiah’s prophecy about the vessels and captives being released?
options: He says Amen and hopes it will come true
questions.correctAnswer: He says Amen and hopes it will come true
questions.explanation: Jeremiah initially responds with 'Amen' and a wish that God would perform Hananiah's words (Jeremiah 28:6).

questions.question: What literary device is illustrated by the contrast between the wooden yoke Hananiah breaks and the iron yoke God commands Jeremiah to proclaim?
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: The broken wooden yoke contrasted with the iron yoke represents irony: Hananiah’s hopeful prophecy is overturned by a harsher reality (Jeremiah 28:13).

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah accuses Hananiah of being sent by the LORD to bring hope to the people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah declares that Hananiah was not sent by the LORD but led the people into trusting a lie (Jeremiah 28:15).

questions.question: What is the significance of Jeremiah delivering his message in the presence of priests and all the people in the house of the LORD?
options: It emphasizes the public and authoritative nature of his prophecy
It was a secret message for the king only
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the public and authoritative nature of his prophecy
questions.explanation: The setting before priests and people highlights the official and communal importance of Jeremiah’s message (Jeremiah 28:1,5).

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 28 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 28 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What prophecy did Hananiah the prophet declare regarding the yoke of the king of Babylon?
options: That the yoke of the king of Babylon would be broken within two full years
That the yoke of the king of Babylon would remain forever
That the people of Judah would serve Babylon for seventy years
That the yoke of the king of Babylon would be made heavier
questions.correctAnswer: That the yoke of the king of Babylon would be broken within two full years
questions.explanation: Hananiah declared in Jeremiah 28:2-4 that the yoke of Babylon would be broken and the captives and vessels returned within two years. This contrasts with Jeremiah’s later prophecy about a longer servitude (cf. 2 Chronicles 36:20-21; Daniel 9:2; Lamentations 5:17; Acts 13:19).

questions.question: How did Jeremiah respond initially to Hananiah's prophecy in the presence of the priests and people?
options: He said, 'Amen: the LORD do so; the LORD perform thy words'
He immediately condemned Hananiah as a false prophet
He remained silent and did not respond
He told the people to ignore Hananiah's words
questions.correctAnswer: He said, 'Amen: the LORD do so; the LORD perform thy words'
questions.explanation: Jeremiah initially said 'Amen' to Hananiah’s prophecy (Jeremiah 28:6), demonstrating a humble openness to God's word, which is consistent with biblical examples of prophets praying for fulfillment of God's promises (cf. Numbers 23:19; 1 Kings 22:13; Isaiah 38:1; Revelation 22:20).

questions.question: What warning did Jeremiah give about prophets who speak peace?
options: They will be known as true if their words come to pass
They are always false and should be ignored
Their peace is from human wisdom, not God
They are inspired by evil spirits
questions.correctAnswer: They will be known as true if their words come to pass
questions.explanation: Jeremiah explained in Jeremiah 28:9 that the true prophet of peace is confirmed when his prophecy is fulfilled, affirming biblical criteria for discerning true prophecy (cf. Deuteronomy 18:21-22; 1 John 4:1; Matthew 7:15-20; 2 Peter 2:1).

questions.question: What symbolic action did Hananiah perform on Jeremiah, and what did it represent?
options: He broke the yoke from Jeremiah’s neck, symbolizing breaking Babylon's oppression
He placed a crown on Jeremiah’s head, symbolizing kingship
He gave Jeremiah a scroll, symbolizing a new covenant
He anointed Jeremiah with oil, symbolizing the Holy Spirit’s empowerment
questions.correctAnswer: He broke the yoke from Jeremiah’s neck, symbolizing breaking Babylon's oppression
questions.explanation: Hananiah broke the wooden yoke from Jeremiah’s neck (Jeremiah 28:10), symbolizing his false message that Babylon’s rule would soon end. This contrasts with God's iron yoke of judgment (Jeremiah 28:13-14), reflecting God's sovereign judgment (cf. Isaiah 10:27; Matthew 11:29-30; Luke 19:11-27; Revelation 2:27).

questions.question: According to God’s word to Jeremiah, what kind of yoke would Hananiah make after breaking the wooden yoke?
questions.correctAnswer: Yokes of iron
questions.explanation: God told Jeremiah that Hananiah would make yokes of iron (Jeremiah 28:13), signifying a stronger, unbreakable bondage under Babylon’s dominion, consistent with biblical imagery of iron symbolizing harsh judgment and authority (cf. Psalm 2:9; Daniel 2:40-43; Revelation 2:27; Revelation 12:5).

questions.question: What reason did Jeremiah give to Hananiah for declaring his prophecy false?
options: Because Hananiah was causing the people to trust in a lie
Because Hananiah was not wearing priestly garments
Because Hananiah had not fasted before prophesying
Because Hananiah was from a foreign land
questions.correctAnswer: Because Hananiah was causing the people to trust in a lie
questions.explanation: Jeremiah said Hananiah was not sent by the LORD and was causing the people to trust a lie (Jeremiah 28:15), highlighting the biblical principle that false prophets lead people astray (cf. Deuteronomy 13:1-5; Jeremiah 23:16; Ezekiel 13:9; Matthew 7:15).

questions.question: What was the divine judgment pronounced against Hananiah for prophesying rebellion?
options: That he would die within the same year
That he would be exiled to Babylon
That he would be imprisoned for life
That he would be struck mute
questions.correctAnswer: That he would die within the same year
questions.explanation: God declared through Jeremiah that Hananiah would die that year because of his rebellion (Jeremiah 28:16), reflecting the Old Testament pattern of immediate judgment on false prophets (cf. 1 Kings 13:1-5; Ezekiel 14:9; Acts 13:10-11; 2 Thessalonians 2:9-12).

questions.question: In which month and year of King Zedekiah’s reign did Hananiah prophesy in the house of the LORD?
options: Fifth month of the fourth year
First month of the third year
Seventh month of the fifth year
Tenth month of the second year
questions.correctAnswer: Fifth month of the fourth year
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:1 specifies the timing of Hananiah's prophecy as the fifth month of the fourth year of King Zedekiah’s reign, providing important historical context aligning with Babylonian captivity events (cf. 2 Kings 25:1-7; Jeremiah 39:1; Ezekiel 24:1; Daniel 1:1).

questions.question: What did God say He had given to Nebuchadnezzar besides the nations under his yoke?
questions.correctAnswer: The beasts of the field
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:14 states that God gave Nebuchadnezzar the beasts of the field as well, symbolizing total dominion over the earth, a theme consistent with God’s sovereignty over creation and nations (cf. Genesis 1:28; Psalm 50:10-11; Daniel 4:17; Romans 13:1).

questions.question: What theological truth about God is revealed by His placing a yoke of iron on the nations to serve Nebuchadnezzar?
options: God's sovereign control over kingdoms and rulers
God’s acceptance of all human rebellion
God’s promise to never judge nations
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereign control over kingdoms and rulers
questions.explanation: The placing of an iron yoke on nations (Jeremiah 28:14) reveals God's sovereign authority over earthly powers, consistent with biblical teaching on God's rule over history (cf. Daniel 2:21; Romans 13:1; Isaiah 45:1-7; Psalm 22:28).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 28 teach about the nature of true prophecy?
options: True prophecy is confirmed by its fulfillment
True prophecy always promises peace and prosperity
True prophecy is only about immediate events
questions.correctAnswer: True prophecy is confirmed by its fulfillment
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:9 emphasizes that a prophet speaking peace is known as truly sent by God only if the prophecy comes to pass, aligning with Deuteronomy 18:21-22 and New Testament affirmations (cf. Matthew 24:24; 1 John 4:1).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 28 portray human sinfulness and rebellion?
options: By highlighting Hananiah's false prophecy as rebellion against God
By showing the people’s immediate repentance
By denying any consequences for sin
questions.correctAnswer: By highlighting Hananiah's false prophecy as rebellion against God
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:15-16 shows Hananiah’s false prophecy as rebellion, illustrating human sinfulness in rejecting God's truth, consistent with biblical teaching on sin as rebellion (cf. Romans 3:23; Isaiah 53:6; Psalm 51:5; 1 John 3:4).

questions.question: What eschatological principle can be derived from the judgment on Hananiah?
options: False teaching leads to swift divine judgment
All prophets will be vindicated at the end of time
False teaching is tolerated in the end times
questions.correctAnswer: False teaching leads to swift divine judgment
questions.explanation: Hananiah’s death within the year (Jeremiah 28:17) exemplifies God’s swift judgment on false prophets, a principle echoed in New Testament warnings about false teachers (cf. 2 Peter 2:1-3; Jude 1:12-13; Revelation 22:18-19; Matthew 7:15-20).

questions.question: What does the contrast between wooden and iron yokes in Jeremiah 28 symbolize theologically?
options: The difference between false hope and divine judgment
The difference between peace and war
The difference between Israel and other nations
The difference between priesthood and kingship
questions.correctAnswer: The difference between false hope and divine judgment
questions.explanation: The wooden yoke represents false hope given by Hananiah, whereas the iron yoke represents God's appointed judgment (Jeremiah 28:13-14), illustrating the biblical theme of God’s righteous justice versus human deception (cf. Ezekiel 4:1; Lamentations 3:27; Matthew 11:30; Romans 8:15).

questions.question: What role do the priests and people have in Jeremiah 28 during Hananiah’s prophecy?
options: They are witnesses to Hananiah's and Jeremiah's words
They write down the prophecies for preservation
questions.correctAnswer: They are witnesses to Hananiah's and Jeremiah's words
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 28:1 and 28:5 mention priests and all the people present during the prophecies, highlighting the communal nature of prophetic proclamation and judgment, consistent with biblical emphasis on public accountability (cf. Deuteronomy 31:11; Nehemiah 8:1-8; Acts 13:15; 1 Corinthians 14:29).
